thread.title: For Rutgers football, moral victories count
thread.title_full: For Rutgers football, moral victories count

title: For Rutgers football, moral victories count
text:
For Rutgers football, moral victories count Stephen Edelson , @steveedelsonAPP 1:02 a.m. EDT October 11, 2015 Rutgers' Janarion Grant returns a kick-off during the second quarter against Michigan State, Saturday, October 10, 2015, in Piscataway, NJ. (Photo: Jason Towlen/Staff Photographer) 29 CONNECT 18 TWEET LINKEDIN 1 COMMENT EMAIL MORE 
PISCATAWAY – Moral victories mean something, at this time, in this place. 
As bitterly disappointing as the 31-24 loss to No. 4 Michigan State was for Rutgers Saturday night, it was nothing short of an inspiring effort by the Scarlet Knights. 
Because while their biggest win since defeating No. 3 Louisville nine years ago would have been nice, what transpired at High Point Solutions Stadium mattered a great deal. 
Back then, the victory over the Cardinals put the program on the big-time college football map. 
This time, in a game in which their fate was sealed on a three-yard TD run with 43 seconds to play, it was all about changing the narrative. 
Because given everything that’s transpired since the start of the season, with seven players arrested and head coach Kyle Flood suspended for three games, Rutgers proved it could still be a competitive force in the Big Ten. 
Assistant head coach Norries Wilson's emotional post-game press conference said it all about the importance of this particular performance. 
We’re talking about football for the time being, and everything seems possible with No. 1 ranked Ohio State coming here in two weeks. The atmosphere at that primetime showdown should be as electric as it was against Michigan State. 
``I think we played really well. We played our butts off,'' safety Andre Hunt said. ``We have a lot of confidence now, playing against the No. 4 team in the country, thinking that down the road we can continue to play like we did tonight we will be able to win more games.’’ 
There wasn’t a black-clad patron in the stands who wasn’t dreaming about what might be possible at halftime. 
And why not. 
Who could blame the Rutgers faithful as the Scarlet Knights took a 14-10 lead. 
It’s what made the ending that much more difficult to stomach, as quarterback Chris Laviano absorbed a sack as he drove the Scarlet Knights into Michigan State territory in the final 30 seconds. He then spiked the ball, as he was instructed to do from the sideline, to stop the clock on what was fourth down, instead of launching a Hail Mary towards the end zone. 
But there was enough here to bolster the program’s spirits. 
``There’s a lot of positives,'' safety Anthony Cioffi said .``It hurts, but we played a great game both sides of the ball. We came up short and now we have to move on from it now.’’ 
Perhaps it was only fitting that Leonte Carroo, reinstated after the simple assault under domestic violence charge against him was dropped last week, returned to show why he’s a potential first-round draft pick, catching a pair of first half touchdown passes, and another in the second half. 
Heroes emerged everywhere. 
Laviano avoided turning the ball over and threw for 208 yards, taking full advantage of Carroo’s return. 
The defensive front put pressure on Spartans quarterback Connor Cook throughout, while containing their ground game. 
Running back Paul James officially announced his return from a knee injury by racing 72 yards to jumpstart the offense, after three stalled drives to open the game. Rutgers upset bid falls just short on late Michigan State TD 
Wilson, in his final game replacing Flood on the sideline, showed he wasn’t playing to lose, going for it on fourth-and-6 with 7:22 to play, with Laviano completing a pass to Justin Goodwin down to the Michigan State 26-yard-line. 
Then Robert Martin carried it for 15 yards to the nine, setting up a game-tying Kyle Federico field goal with 4:21 to play. 
But ultimately, it was Cook who engineered a 77-yard drive for the game-winning touchdown, keeping the Spartans’ dream of winning a national championship alive. 
For Rutgers, it was about getting the focus back on the football field, which is exactly what happened. 
And in the process, the Scarlet Knights gained respect throughout the Big Ten. 
Staff writer Stephen Edelson is an Asbury Park Press columnist: sedelson@gannettnj.com 29 CONNECT 18 TWEET LINKEDIN 1 COMMENT EMAIL MORE Read or Share this story: http://on.app.com/1RAw0En TOP VIDEOS
